title: Dart Colliding with Block attached to ceiling

content.question: This question is a long free-response question. Show your work for each part of the question. (12 points, suggested time 25 minutes) A block with mass <math alttext="uppercase M sub 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>M</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> hangs at rest from a string that is attached to a ceiling. A dart with mass <math alttext="lowercase m sub D" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>m</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>D</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> is moving horizontally with speed <math alttext="v sub 0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>v</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> immediately before colliding with the block, as shown in Figure <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>I</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. The dart remains embedded in the block. The center of mass of the dart-block system swings up to a maximum height <math alttext="h sub 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>h</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> above its initial position before stopping momentarily, as shown in Figure <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>II</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. (a) The dart collides with the block at time <math alttext="t sub C" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>C</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, and the center of mass of the dart-block system reaches its maximum height at time <math alttext="t sub F" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>F</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>. i. Consider the dart-block-Earth system. <math alttext="E" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>E</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is the total mechanical energy of the dart-block-Earth system, and immediately before time <math alttext="t sub C" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>C</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> it is equal to <math alttext="E sub 0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>E</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>. On the axes below, sketch <math alttext="E" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>E</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> as a function of time <math alttext="t" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> for <math alttext="t equals t sub C" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><msub><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>C</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> to <math alttext="t equals t sub F" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><msub><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>F</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>.

frqParts.text: This question is a long free-response question. Show your work for each part of the question. (12 points, suggested time 25 minutes) A block with mass <math alttext="uppercase M sub 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>M</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> hangs at rest from a string that is attached to a ceiling. A dart with mass <math alttext="lowercase m sub D" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>m</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>D</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> is moving horizontally with speed <math alttext="v sub 0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>v</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> immediately before colliding with the block, as shown in Figure <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>I</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. The dart remains embedded in the block. The center of mass of the dart-block system swings up to a maximum height <math alttext="h sub 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>h</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> above its initial position before stopping momentarily, as shown in Figure <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>II</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. (a) The dart collides with the block at time <math alttext="t sub C" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>C</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, and the center of mass of the dart-block system reaches its maximum height at time <math alttext="t sub F" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>F</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>. i. Consider the dart-block-Earth system. <math alttext="E" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>E</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is the total mechanical energy of the dart-block-Earth system, and immediately before time <math alttext="t sub C" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>C</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> it is equal to <math alttext="E sub 0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>E</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>. On the axes below, sketch <math alttext="E" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>E</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> as a function of time <math alttext="t" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> for <math alttext="t equals t sub C" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><msub><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>C</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> to <math alttext="t equals t sub F" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><msub><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>F</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>.

ii. Now consider the system containing just the block and the dart. The magnitude of the momentum of the dart-block system is <math alttext="p" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, and immediately before time <math alttext="t sub C" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>C</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> it is equal to <math alttext="p sub 0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>. On the axes below, sketch <math alttext="p" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> as a function of time <math alttext="t" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> for <math alttext="t equals t sub C" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><msub><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>C</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> to <math alttext="t equals t sub F" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><msub><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>F</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(b) The block is replaced with a different block of mass <math alttext="uppercase M sub 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>M</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, where <math alttext="uppercase M sub 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>M</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> is greater than <math alttext="uppercase M sub 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>M</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>. The experiment is repeated with the same dart moving horizontally at the same speed <math alttext="v sub 0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>v</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, and the center of mass of this dart-block system reaches a maximum height <math alttext="h sub 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>h</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> above its initial position. How does <math alttext="h sub 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>h</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> compare to <math alttext="h sub 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>h</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>? ____ <math alttext="h sub 2 is less than h sub 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>h</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo><</mo><msub><mrow><mi>h</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> ____ <math alttext="h sub 2 equals h sub 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>h</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mrow><mi>h</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> ____ <math alttext="h sub 2 is greater than h sub 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>h</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mrow><mi>h</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> Without including equations in your response, explain your reasoning.

(c) Consider the general case of a block of mass <math alttext="uppercase M sub B" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>M</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>B</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> hanging at rest and a dart of mass <math alttext="lowercase m sub D" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>m</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>D</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> moving horizontally with speed <math alttext="v sub 0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>v</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>. The dart hits and embeds in the block, and the center of mass of the dart-block system swings up to a maximum height <math alttext="h" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>h</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> above its initial position. Derive an equation for <math alttext="h" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>h</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> in terms of <math alttext="lowercase m sub D" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>m</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>D</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="uppercase M sub B" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>M</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>B</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="v sub 0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>v</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, and physical constants, as appropriate.

(d) Consider the scenario in part (b) above, where the block has mass <math alttext="uppercase M sub 2 is greater than uppercase M sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>M</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mrow><mi>M</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>. Does your general equation for the maximum height from part (c) agree with your reasoning in part (b)?____ Yes ____ NoExplain how your general equation from part (c) either supports or does not support your reasoning in part (b).

skill.text: 1.C: Create qualitative sketches of graphs that represent features of a model or the behavior of a physical system.
